name: D&D 5e Terminology Reference
description: Common D&D terminology for AI parsing and natural language understanding. Each term includes its definition and common aliases players might use.

terms.definition: A d20 roll + ability modifier + proficiency bonus (if proficient in the relevant skill). Used to determine success or failure for non-combat tasks.
A d20 roll + ability modifier + proficiency bonus (if proficient). Used to resist spells, traps, poisons, diseases, and similar threats.
A d20 roll + ability modifier + proficiency bonus. Compared against the target's AC to determine if an attack hits.
A number representing how hard a creature is to hit. An attack roll must meet or exceed the target's AC to hit.
A numerical representation of a creature's vitality. When HP reaches 0, the creature falls unconscious or dies.
A bonus that increases with character level (+2 at level 1, up to +6 at level 17). Added to attack rolls, ability checks, saving throws, and spell DCs when the character is proficient.
Roll two d20s and take the higher result. Granted by favorable circumstances, spells, or abilities.
Roll two d20s and take the lower result. Imposed by unfavorable circumstances, conditions, or abilities.
A natural 20 on an attack roll. Automatically hits and doubles the number of damage dice rolled.
The target number for a saving throw or ability check. Set by the DM or defined by a spell/ability.
A Dexterity check that determines the order of turns in combat. Higher initiative goes first.
Some spells require ongoing focus. Taking damage forces a Constitution saving throw (DC 10 or half damage, whichever is higher) to maintain. Only one concentration spell at a time.
The main thing a character does on their turn: Attack, Cast a Spell, Dash, Disengage, Dodge, Help, Hide, Ready, Search, or Use an Object.
An extra action available only when a class feature, spell, or ability specifically grants one. Limited to one per turn.
An instant response to a trigger, taken on another creature's turn. Limited to one per round. Examples: Opportunity Attack, Shield spell, Counterspell.
A resource expended to cast a spell of that level or lower. Recovered on a long rest (short rest for Warlocks).
A spell that can be cast at will without expending a spell slot. Damage cantrips scale with character level.
A period of at least 1 hour during which a character does nothing more strenuous than eating, drinking, reading, and tending wounds. Can spend Hit Dice to heal.

A period of at least 8 hours during which a character sleeps for at least 6 hours and performs no more than 2 hours of light activity. Restores all HP, recovers half of spent Hit Dice, and resets most abilities.
Dice representing a creature's vitality. A character has one hit die per level. Can be spent during a short rest to recover HP.
Extra HP that are lost first before regular HP. Do not stack (take the highest value). Cannot be healed back once lost.
A d20 roll with no modifiers made when a creature starts its turn with 0 HP. DC 10: success. Three successes = stabilized. Three failures = death. Natural 20 = regain 1 HP. Natural 1 = two failures.
A reaction melee attack made when a hostile creature moves out of your reach without Disengaging.
Terrain that costs 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot traveled. Examples: rubble, ice, undergrowth, stairs.
A cumulative condition with increasing penalties. Each level imposes a -2 penalty to d20 rolls. At 6 levels, the creature dies. Levels are removed one at a time by long rests.
A creature with resistance to a damage type takes half damage from that type (rounded down).
A creature with vulnerability to a damage type takes double damage from that type.
A creature with immunity to a damage type or condition takes no damage of that type or is unaffected by that condition.
A magical bond between a creature and a magic item, requiring a short rest to establish. A creature can attune to a maximum of three items at once.
An item (arcane focus, holy symbol, druidic focus, or component pouch) that can be used in place of non-costly, non-consumed material components for spells.
A character that takes levels in more than one class. Requires meeting ability score prerequisites (usually 13 in the primary ability of both classes).
A DM reward (or rolled on a natural 20) that allows a player to reroll one d20 test before the outcome is determined. A creature can have only one instance of Heroic Inspiration at a time.
